utterances: Mm-hmm.
Let's hear the transition.
(SOUNDBITE OF SONG, ""INTERLUDE"")
That's a transition.
(SOUNDBITE OF SONG, ""I AM WOMAN"")
(Singing) Said I am woman, you are man.
I Am Woman"" is just basically enough - I've had enough of somebody taking advantage of me.
Where does it come from?
I'm very much into, like, environment and stuff.
I wanted to make a voice for a planet to, like, humankind.
And I was influenced by that, but it could go for women as well being tired of, you know, being taken advantage of a man.
I understand what you're saying, but this does not feel political.
Yeah.
It's very sneaky.
(SOUNDBITE OF SONG, ""I AM WOMAN"")
(Singing) (Unintelligible)
You talk about these songs taking us on a journey telling a story.
People don't listen to music that way so much anymore.
I know.
They'll load these into their iPod or their iPhone or their whatever and hit shuffle, and they'll come up.
Is that OK?
I don't think so.
I think we need to take time and sit down and listen to music.
I don't think we do that enough anymore.
But a lot of artists, you know, we put so much time, and we put so much thought and put our hearts into our music.
And to just pick and choose, you know, it's kind of sad.
That's Irene Diaz.
Her EP is called ""I Love You Madly"" and was just released at the beginning of the month.
Irene, thanks for speaking with us.
Thank you.
Can't wait to hear what's next.
Thank you so much.

(Singing) You fill out my day with songs...
And for Saturday that's WEEKENDS on ALL THINGS CONSIDERED from NPR News.
I'm Don Gonyea.

Until then, thanks for listening and have a great night.
NPR's business news starts with the Texas Rangers.
(Soundbite of music)
We can now tell you that a group of investors won a federal bankruptcy auction early this morning to buy the baseball team.
The investors are led by Hall of Fame pitcher and current Rangers president, Nolan Ryan.
The franchise has been in bankruptcy since May.
Ryan's winning bid for the team is worth $593 million.
His group managed to beat out billionaire Mark Cuban, who owns the Dallas Mavericks basketball team.
The auction dragged on for 10 hours.
And at one point, Cuban's side received a delivery of 10 pizzas in the courthouse.
It's the first auction of a Major League Baseball team since the Baltimore Orioles were sold in 1993.
Forty of the country's wealthiest families and individuals have pledged to give at least half of their wealth to charity.
It's part of a campaign led by billionaires Warren Buffett and Bill Gates, who are both giving away most of their enormous fortunes.
They're now joined by movie director George Lucas, former Citigroup CEO Sandy Weill and software mogul Larry Ellison, among others.
Buffett and Gates launched the effort earlier this year because the recession has cut into charitable giving for the past two years.
In the days after the shooting, the Army sent a number of chaplains to Fort Hood.
Their job was to counsel soldiers.
The chaplains included Major Dawud Agbere.
Hes a native of Ghana, in West Africa.
Hes now served a decade in the United States Army, and hes one of the Armys six Muslim chaplains.
There are chaplains from a variety of religions.
Major Agbere says hes been moving around the base, meeting troops at Fort Hood.
Above all, he listens.
You have soldiers who are just asking why, just like everybodys asking why.
Why should such a thing happen?
And we give them other perspectives, the big picture, so that they just dont concentrate on just one single event.
We want to encourage them to keep on going and see this as out of human life.
We should make clear for people who may not know: Youre not just seeing Muslim soldiers, are you?
What goes in the clubhouse stays in the clubhouse - until the baseball manager writes a book, that is.
It's Thursday, and if you haven't guessed, it's time again for a look at sports with our very own sports guru, the New York Times Sports Columnist, Mr. Bill Rhoden.
Mr. Bill, what's up?
Hey, the great Tony Cox.
How you're doing?
I'm doing great, man.
Joe Torre, leaving New York as a beloved figure, but now he has written his autobiography, ""The Yankee Years."" I know that he's been on his New York tour.
People are buying the book.
But, you know, some people are happy, some people not so happy.
Well, the people who are most important to be happy are happy.
The publisher of course...
(Soundbite of laugher)
Anybody reading book, it's about selling books.
And I, Tony, I sort of equate it to in football, the most important statistics for a receiver are yards after catch.
That's true.

And that's what the book is about, yards after catch and, you know, people are talking about, you know, why isn't Derek Jeter or anybody saying, you know, Derek's job is not to, you know, throw down field blocks, you know, for Torre, I mean it's - listen, man, it's - it's all good.
People are talking about it and, you know Torre is - yeah, he's not making anything up.
Well, I'll tell you what, out here in California, the owner of the Dodgers, Frank McCourt, apparently has told Torre that he can't write a book here.
He can write one, but not two.
Is this a big deal now, these guys writing these books, giving away what goes on behind closed doors?

I mean, I think you're going to see if - I think what you're going to see is a lot owners and general managers, you know, telling clubs, hey listen, you're going to have to sign a contract that you cannot, you know, do this.
That you're going to sign a non-disclosure form that what goes on in the club policy, in the corporation stays here.
But it's too bad for us because as media, we love this stuff.
Absolutely.
Let's talk about somebody else who's in the media every once in a while, Barry Bonds.
Yeah.
Trial is set to get underway.
He's pleaded not guilty for the third time.
A federal judge unsealing documents the prosecutors say prove that Bonds knew he was using performance enhancing drugs.
So, are we getting closer to something actually happening or is this thing going to just drag on forever?
Well, you know, it depends, Tony.
What this document doesn't necessarily prove that Bonds knew.

And that's the missing link here, when it proves - and it depends on what - what goes into evidence, it proves there was a conversation about it, it proves that there was an informant who was trying to set up Bonds and Greg Anderson.
What's not really decided, does it really prove that Bonds knew, but beyond a shadow of a doubt.
Right now, the trial is set for March 2nd.
I really wish, I mean, with the economy the way it is, they're spending millions of dollars on this pursuit.
I think they should just give it up.
They should settle.
Bonds' career is already ruined.
He's not getting into the hall of fame.
I think they should go over to him and say, listen, enough is enough.
We're going to stop this chase and we're going to settle this out of court.
Well, you know it's interesting how different media personalities in sports are dealt with when it comes to the issue of illegal substances.
I'm talking now about eight-time gold medalist, Michael Phelps who gave people an idea of what the fish does out of water...
(Soundbite of laugher)
When pictures surfaced this week showing what appears to be Mr. Phelps smoking a bong - presumably with Marijuana in it.

He's apologized but, you know, let's talk about the impact that this will have on his endorsement deals and also whether or not his treatment in the press is different for a significant reason than the way Barry Bonds is treated.
The treatment is - let's start with the treatment first.
I was just at the Super Bowl and Santonio Holmes was the most valuable player.
And as you know, in October he was caught with some marijuana in his car.
